posts.cooked:
For many years our team only had one coder. He left after the year I joined and I am never got a full explanation about how all the code works. The main thing I have been copying with no understanding is velocity / position conversion. We use CANEncoders and use this line to set velocity / position conversion.

private val rightEnc = rightMaster.encoder.apply { velocityConversionFactor = (1 / 60.0) * (Constants.DRIVE_WHEEL_RADIUS.meters * 2 * PI) / 9.9 positionConversionFactor = (Constants.DRIVE_WHEEL_RADIUS.meters * 2 * PI) / 9.9 }

This is kotlin so velocityConversionFactor calls setVelocityConversionFactor()

I get that 1 / 60.0 is the gear ratio and  (Constants.DRIVE_WHEEL_RADIUS.meters * 2 * PI)

The question I have is why is there a random division by 9.9?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Gaaa! A wild magic number appears!

I can’t think of any physical constant that’s evaluating to 9.9 exactly, unfortunately. There are smarter people here than me though, they may have an idea.

One thing I see missing in the conversion formulas above is some way to account for the Counts-per-revolution in the encoder . However, this number is usually an integer.

This gets more into psychology than programming but… would you say the author of the code had a propensity to guess-and-check? There’s a chance it might also just be a fudge factor that they threw in, tweaked until the output “looked close enough”, and never went back to figure out its physical meaning.

link_counts.title: What’s an Encoder’s PPR, CPR, and LPR? | CUI Devices

posts.cooked:
Hi! So, let’s start out with dimensional analysis . Read the hyperlinked text and look up some YouTube videos to get a better understanding .

Now, we can move on to what a velocity / position conversion is. When we get values from the motor, we usually get the number of revolutions that the motor has done or RPM (revolutions per minute. In order to get our robot to move the way we want Odometry wise we want to change those units to something like m/s or ft/s (velocity) or m  (position). That is what your conversion factor is doing, converting from motor based units (the revolutions) to units that are useful to us (be that meters, meters/s, etc.)

So, write out the dimensional analysis, and you will see that the 9.9 number is most likely the gearing of your robot (check with your build team to see if this is right). For every rotation of your motor, the output shaft of your gearbox/ the final gear will turn 1/(GEARING). If your motor rotates 9.9 times, the output shaft will turn 1 time because of the gears. I would ask your mentors/build team (or someone else on here) for a more rigorous explanation on gearing.

In the velocity conversion factor, 1/60.0 is used to get units/s. Units is meters judging from your code.

Now it’s up to you to fix this for your future programmers: Made a variable for gearing and make sure you show your calculations in your code, don’t just write down your final answer and call it a day.

link_counts.title: Introduction to Kinematics and The Chassis Speeds Class — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
gerthworm:

This gets more into psychology than programming but… would you say the author of the code had a propensity to guess-and-check? There’s a chance it might also just be a fudge factor that they threw in, tweaked until the output “looked close enough”, and never went back to figure out its physical meaning.

For reference: never do this .  It isn’t even likely to work well temporarily.  Units are one thing you must handle correctly in your code.
